Liberal Club To Hear
Mrs. Geoffrey May On
War Debt Situation
Mrs. Geoffrey May, of the Department of Economics and Sociology at Goucher College, will address the Liberal Club today on the
subject "Reparations and War
Debts". Mrs. May, who received
her Ph.D. in Economics from the
University of London, will discuss
the current aspects of the situation.
At today's meeting the club will
talk over plans for the sending of
delegates to two student conferences
which are to convene during the
Christmas holidays. They are the
Student Congress Against War,
which will meet in Chicago, and the
League for Industrial Democracy,
to confer in New York.

As his third and final reason for
opposing armed conflict, Mr.
Blanchard stated that, fundamentally, all the major conflicts between
great powers are economic in nature
and are fought either for the protection of foreign investments, for
acquiring more trade or for the
control of further sources of raw
materials. It would be rather hard,
he said, to enlist an army for the
avowed purpose of saving the investments of Mr. Morgan in France
and England or the Doheny oil reserves in Mexico. The fact that no
one is agitating that France be invaded for non-payment of her debts
to this country is evidence of some
advancement, perhaps, but upon
glancing at the situation in Haiti, it
becomes more likely, evidence of
belief that discretion is the better
part of valor, he said.

Professor McKibben told of the
"roman bridge" which he had designed. This is the Ridge Road
bridge across the Genessee River,
near Rochester, N. Y.

Dr. W.S. Thayer
Wills Body To
Scientific Study
Names Drs. MacCallum And
Meyer To Perform
Operations
The body of Dr. William S.
Thayer, whose sudden death last
Sunday morning in Washington
shocked the medical world, has been
bequeathed by the noted Johns
Hopkins physician to the interest
of science. This request was made
in his will, which was filed in Orphans Court on Wednesday.
Dr. William MacCallum, a close
friend of the deceased, was named
to conduct the necropsy. The will
also recommended that Dr. Thayer's
brain be placed at the disposal of
Dr. Adolph Meyer, famous alienist.
Bequeaths Books, Prints

The large collection of valuable
books and prints possessed by Dr.
Thayer was bequeathed to Harvard
University. His medical books were
left to the Welch Library of the
Hopkins.
Dr. Thayer had held his usual
clinic at the Johns Hopkins Hospital at noon Saturday and had
spoken Friday at a dinner of the
Carnegie Institution of Washington.
Dedicatory Address

As professor emeritus of medicine, he had delivered the dedicatory address at the formal opening
of the Osler Medical Clinic, October 28. His studies of heart diseases had made him a world authority on the subject. He was one
of the men responsible for Baltimore's rise to fame as a medical
center.
. Dr. Thayer served as president
of the American Medical Association from 1928-1929. During the
World Wart he was chief medical
consultant of the American Expeditionary Forces.
World-Wide Fame
Had Dr. Thayer lived two more
years he would have been feted
throughout the world, for his colleagues and former students had
planned an international celebration
on his seventieth birthday, June 23,
1934. Tributes from men of medicine from all parts of the world
were being collected into a memorial volume for the occasion.

writing and selling articles. Negroes
compose 60 to 65 percent of the population.

which it is hard for the outsider to

Liberal Club To Hear
Mrs. Geoffrey May On
War Debt Situation
Mrs. Geoffrey May, of the Department of Economics and Sociology at Goucher College, will address the Liberal Club today on the
subject "Reparations and War
Debts". Mrs. May, who received
her Ph.D. in Economics from the
University of London, will discuss
the current aspects of the situation.
At today's meeting the club will
talk over plans for the sending of
delegates to two student conferences
which are to convene during the
Christmas holidays. They are the
Student Congress Against War,
which will meet in Chicago, and the
League for Industrial Democracy,
to confer in New York.

As his third and final reason for
opposing armed conflict, Mr.
Blanchard stated that, fundamentally, all the major conflicts between
great powers are economic in nature
and are fought either for the protection of foreign investments, for
acquiring more trade or for the
control of further sources of raw
materials. It would be rather hard,
he said, to enlist an army for the
avowed purpose of saving the investments of Mr. Morgan in France
and England or the Doheny oil reserves in Mexico. The fact that no
one is agitating that France be invaded for non-payment of her debts
to this country is evidence of some
advancement, perhaps, but upon
glancing at the situation in Haiti, it
becomes more likely, evidence of
belief that discretion is the better
part of valor, he said.

Professor McKibben told of the
"roman bridge" which he had designed. This is the Ridge Road
bridge across the Genessee River,
near Rochester, N. Y.

At the December

meeting of the club last Tuesday,
Paul Blanshard, director of the
City Affairs Commission of New
York, substituted for Rabbi Stephen
S. Wise, the scheduled speaker, discussing "Why I Became A War Resister."
Beginning his speech by a statement of the necessity of keeping up
the campaign against war because

Dr. W.S. Thayer
Wills Body To
Scientific Study
Names Drs. MacCallum And
Meyer To Perform
Operations
The body of Dr. William S.
Thayer, whose sudden death last
Sunday morning in Washington
shocked the medical world, has been
bequeathed by the noted Johns
Hopkins physician to the interest
of science. This request was made
in his will, which was filed in Orphans Court on Wednesday.
Dr. William MacCallum, a close
friend of the deceased, was named
to conduct the necropsy. The will
also recommended that Dr. Thayer's
brain be placed at the disposal of
Dr. Adolph Meyer, famous alienist.
Bequeaths Books, Prints

The large collection of valuable
books and prints possessed by Dr.
Thayer was bequeathed to Harvard
University. His medical books were
left to the Welch Library of the
Hopkins.
Dr. Thayer had held his usual
clinic at the Johns Hopkins Hospital at noon Saturday and had
spoken Friday at a dinner of the
Carnegie Institution of Washington.
Dedicatory Address

As professor emeritus of medicine, he had delivered the dedicatory address at the formal opening
of the Osler Medical Clinic, October 28. His studies of heart diseases had made him a world authority on the subject. He was one
of the men responsible for Baltimore's rise to fame as a medical
center.
. Dr. Thayer served as president
of the American Medical Association from 1928-1929. During the
World Wart he was chief medical
consultant of the American Expeditionary Forces.
World-Wide Fame
Had Dr. Thayer lived two more
years he would have been feted
throughout the world, for his colleagues and former students had
planned an international celebration
on his seventieth birthday, June 23,
1934. Tributes from men of medicine from all parts of the world
were being collected into a memorial volume for the occasion.
